cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office, London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.Le reaesu de eables telegraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie constitue le moyen de communication le plus direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amerique du Nord et du Sud, l'Afrique orientale, meridionale et occidentale, les Indes, l''Austraile, la Nouvelle-Zelande, la Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les telerammee doivent porter l'indication Via Eastern.Voir le tempe moyen de transmission le plus recent jusque Londres au bulletin journalier publie dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Bureau priscipal a Londres.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: The following steamers are expected to leave Port Said on or about the following dates:--
Port-Said to London via Brindisi
The BRINDISI steamer leaves PORT-SAID after arrival of Indian Mail. Combined steamer and sleeping car fare from PORT-SAID to LONDON via BRINDISI or via MARSEILLES £25.9.11
To the East.

The Mail Steamers leave SUEZ for ADEN and BOMBAY every Wednesday, and for AUSTRALIA and CHINA every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for CALCUTTA, fortnightly, and another for JAPAN. Passengers can embark at PORT-SAID.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. Thos, Cook & Son (Egypt) Ltd.… … … … … … … … CAIRO.
George Royle, Esq… … … … … … … … … … … … … … PORT-SAID.
Messrs. Haselden & Co. … … … … … … … … … … … … ALEXANDRIA.
F.G. DAVIDSON, Superintendant P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt. SUEZ. 81-12-90

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. Orotava will leave Suez about Dec. 2
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. Ortona will leave Port-Said about Dec. 5
N.B.-Homeward steamers are sometimes before their advertised dates.
Passengers landed and embarked at Ismalia, Quarantine Regulations permitting, free of all expense.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of one-third of their fare back if the return voyage be within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 % if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 81-12-904

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Special Reduced Rates During Summer Season,
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Warwickshire 7,968 tons, will leave Suez about December 7.
S.S. Cheshire 5,708 tons, will leave Suez about December 21.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, will leave Port-Said about Novemer 29.
S.S. Shropshire 5,720 tons will leave Port-Said about December 13.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.

Fitted with Refrigerators, Electric Light, Electric fans and all recent improvements. Experienced Stewardesses and burgeons carried.--Agents in Cairo: Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & SONS, Port-Said & Port-Tewfik (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Belgrade, Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
Steamers leave Suez every Thursday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, calling as required at TOR (for Mount Sinai) and YAMBO, and continuing in alernate weeks to SUAKIM, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.
Return tickets available for six months.--For terms of freight or passage apply to H.J. Moss & Co., Alexandria, Agents.
S.S. NITOCRIS now on the berth, will sail on or about Tuesday, November 29,to be followed by S.S. SETI.
Through rates of freight to Lanceshire inland towns, to Boston, New-York and either U.S.A. towns, can be abtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application. 26-11-904

EXPRESS SERVICE- Steamers leave Cairo every Monday and Friday during the season for Luxor, Assouan, and Philae. 20 days on the Nile for £22.
Special combined railway and steamer Nile tours at greatly reduced fares. Bi-Weekly service to Halfa, Khartoum, & Sudan.
Special steamers and dahabeahs for private parties. Regular Service of Freight Steamers between CAIRO and HALFA.
Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway Stations and Loading-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their tickets.
Tours to Palestine, Syria, and Desert. Best Camp equipment, Lowest charges. 10-18-904

S.S. "ITRIA," will sail from Suez on or about the 14th December.

REMARKS.- Surgeons and Stewardesses carried. Ice rooms, Punkahs, and every comfort for a tropical climate. Passengers and Cargo booked through to Continental and American Ports and to all important Ports on Coast of India, Persian Gulf, East Africa, Burmah, Straits Settlements, Eastern Archipelago, Java and Queensland Ports. Rates of Passage money, as below, include table for First and Second Class Passengers only, but not wines or spirits, which may be had on board for payment. Passengers are allowed to break the voyage at any intermediate Ports and proceed by following steamer in which there may be accomodation.

div.head: HOTEL BRISTOL, CAIRO.
div.p: Full South, Electric Light, opposite Esbekieh Gardens, Large Verandahs, Moderate Charges, OHAS. BAUER, Proprietor.

This Hotel is beautifully fitted up and is in the most central part of Cairo. The terms for pension are at the rate of ten shillings a day. Special terms for officers of the Army of Occupation. 24,882-81-10 905

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift, Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - SPLENDID GARDEN. - OMNIBUS MEET ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor. 28745-28-2-905

div.p: CAPITAL: L. 2,500,000. RESERVE (environ) : L. 700,000.

Siège Social au Caire, Succursale à Alexandria, Agence à Assiout, Assuoan, Benha, Beni-Suef, Chibin el Kom, Damanhour, Fayoum, Khartoum, Kéneh, Mansourah. Minieh, Port-Said, Suakin, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig, Mouski (Caire) et Londres (4 et 5, King William Street).

LA NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s'occupe de l'achat et de la vente d'effets sur l'Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 81-12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Alexandria-Patras-Brindisi-Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 23rd November, 7th and 21st December.
Far East Line.

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about Dec. 5. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about 9th Dec.. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about November 20.
East African Line.
To Aden, Momhasea, Zanaibar, Belra, Delagoa Bay, Durban about December 4.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.
Steamers leaves Alexandria on or about November 14 and 28, December 12 and 26.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about November 21, December 5 and 19.
For information apply to the Company's Agents, Alexandria, Port Said and Suez, Thos. Cook & Son, Ld., Leon Heller, Cairo Agent, 4, Sharia Maghraby, (Telephone 192), Cairo; F. Tedeschi, Helouan.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Continual calm weather prevailed throughout yesterday, followed at midnight by a flat calm, with a calm sea, the weather being slightly hasy. A little dew fell throughout the night. Barometer steady.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.-Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 281 1/3 per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 278 (£2.16s.) per annum.

ADVERTISEMENTS.- P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20, every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news columns P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements. N.B.-Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price One Plastre Tarrif.
THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1904.

div.head: STREET NOMENCLATURE.
div.p: Some months ago the Post Office Administration notified the public that in future correspondents should, in addressing their letters, never fail to give the name of the street and the number of the house where the addressee resided. The penalty for failing to comply with this regulation was delay in the delivery of the letters imperfectly addressed. It was pointed out in our columns at the time that many streets in Cairo were utterly unbaptizes, while more often than not the Public Works Administration appeared to regard the affixing of numbers to houses as one of the superfluities of civilization. After the Post Office Administration had issued the notice in question, some attempts were made by the Public Works Department to name a few streets in Cario, but it appears that the efforts have been relaxed for there are many streets in the Capital which are innocent of any designation whatsoever. We may instance three or four streets running off the Kasr-el-Ainy-road, on the left as one goes towards the hospital from Kasr-el-Nil Bridge. These streets are nameless, and therefore the regulation of the Post office cannot be complied with. It has been maliciously rumoured that the reason why so many streets are unnamed is because of the jealousy among officials, who cannot come to any agreement among themselves and to which of them shall be immortalized by christening the streets with their own names. This is ridiculous, for the modesty of our official classes is proverbial. But we fail to see any reason why the names of prominent Anglo-Egyptians should not figure on the street as well as those of native notables, such as Idris Bey Ragheb, whose name adorns a street near El Daher, and also in other cases. At Alexandria we have streets named after Goussio, Adib, Antonisdis, Gordon, Mariette, and numerous other local notabilties. Surely there are plenty of officials belonging to the Public Works Department or the Ministries of Justice and the Interior whose names would be useful for these streets ! Such names as Garstin, Dunlop, or McIlwraith might fittingly be adapted to street nomenclature. As the roads we have mentioned are in the neighbourhood of the new schools by the Kasr-el-Ainy-road it would be appropriate to use some of the names of the high officials in the Ministry of Public Instruction, such as that of Dr. Dunlop, Yacoub Pasha Artin, etc. The opportunities thus afforded for immortalizing many names whose owners are closely connected with the development of modern Egypt would be unllimited, as new streets are springing up daily. Another plan, in case of disagreement, would be to put the matter up to an auction, as there must be many who would be only too eager to see their names inscribed on the walls of Cairo for all time. The sum realised should be of great utility in swelling the revenues of the Tanzim Department, which pleads poverty as an excuse for neglecting its duties towards the public.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR.
NAVAL BOMBARDMENT.
ARSENAL IN DANGER.
div.p: Tokio, November 23.
Five submarines arrived at Yokohama to-day. The bombardment by the naval guns ignited the buildings near the Arsenal at Port Arthur. They were burning all yesterday. (Reuter.)
Tokio, November 23.
The buildings situated near the Arsenal at Port Arthur have been set on fire by the Japanese naval guns. Five submarines have arrived at Yokohama (Havas.)

div.head: JAPAN BUYING WELSH COAL.
div.p: London, November 23.
Japan is again buying Welsh steam coal. Several Cardiff firms are making offers. One purchase of 10,000 tons has been recorded (Reuter.)

div.head: CREW OF THE "RAZTORPAY."
div.p: Chi-Fu, November 23.
The crew of the Ratztorpay will be conveyed to Shanghai by the Chinese cruiser Haiyung with the consent of the Japanese and Russian Governments. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN INTERRESTS.
THREATENED BY GREAT BRITAIN.
div.p: St.Petersburg, November 23.
The Rus urges Russia to defend her interests in the Near and Middle East with greater vigour than ever, otherwise south-eastern Persia and the Gulf will soon be British possessions. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE NORTH SEA OUTRAGE.
MEMORIAL TO VICTIMS.
div.p: Hull, November 23.
A memorial by public subscription will be erected here for the victims of the Baltic Fleet. (Reuter.)

div.head: CHINA AND THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
div.p: Amsterdam, November 23.
China has consented to be represented at the Hague Conference. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN REFORM.
div.p: THE ZEMSTVOS MEETING.
St.Petersburg, November 23.

The meeting of the zemstvos closed yesterday evening. Though held privately, it attracted the greatest attention. The discussions, which were unrestricted, covered a wide field. The greatest unanimity in favour of reform was manifested. The delegates will present a programine to the Minister of the Interior, and it is repeated that the same will be received by the Tsar. (Reuter.)

div.head: A TURKISH EXPEDITION.
div.p: TURKEY BUYING CAMELS.
CONSTANTINOPLE, November 23.
Turkey is purchasing a large number of camels at Basra: it is believed they are for an expedition into the Nejd country against the chief Ibn Saied. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive is expected to return to Cairo on Friday evening or Saturday morning.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: A MAD DOG bit a native girl of 6 years, yesterday, near the Alexandria Custonm-house. She has been sent to Cairo for treatment at the Anti-Rabic Institute.

NEW ROADS.-The Ministry of Public Works proposes to make new roads at Zeitoun and Matarieh. Proprietors of land in these places will, it is hoped, facilitate matters by coming to the assistance of the Ministry.

TELEPHONE Co. OF EGYPT.-Application has been made to the London Exchange Committee to appoint a special settling day in and to grant a quotation to: Telephone Company of Egypt, <pound symbol>60,000 4 ½ per cent. Debenture Stock.

SUDAN EXPLORATION.-An application has been made to the London Stock Exchange Committee to appoint a special settling day in Sudan Exploration, further issue of 15,000 shares of 10s, each fully paid, Nos.40,008 to 55,007.

RAILWAY ACCIDENT.-A train on the Ramleh Electric Railway ran over and severly injured a native yesterday near Chatby station. The driver of the car has been arrested. The injured man is lying in the Government Hospital, where no hope is entertained of his recovery,

CHURCH OF SCOTLAND WOMAN'S GUILD.- A sale of work in connection with the St. Andrew's branch of the guild will be held in the boys upper school, Missala quarter, on Friday, 16th December. After defraying the expenses of material, etc., the proceeds will go towards the purchase of a piano for the Seamen's Home.

SUEZ CANAL.- On the 21st inst. 8 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 7 were British and 1 Dutch. The transit and passenget dues for the day amounted to 237,626.86 frs. The total transit an passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 256 vessels amounted to 6,848,766.41 francs.

M. SIEVAIN, the celebrated French actor, is paying a return visit to Alexandria to-morrow. In the afternoon he will deliver a lecture at the Khedivial Hotel on "L' Art de Dire" and in the evening, by special request, will appear at the Zizinia Theatre in Moreas's Iphigenie, in which he scored a huge succes at a performance given recently in the Stadium at Athens

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: It is said that H.H. the Khedive will confer the rank of Mirmiran (pasha) on Mohamed Bey Surur, of the Wakfs Administration, in the coming year.
Lord Cromer paid a visit last Monday to the Survey Department at Gizeh.
The Persian Consul at Alexandria left for Cairo yesterday.
Seandar Pasha Fehmy left yesterday for Cairo by the noon train.
Captain Hall, R.E., goods manager of the State Railways, is, we are sorry to hear, suffering from an attack of diphtheria, and is an inmate of the Deaconsesses' Hospital, Cairo.
Mr. H.A. Gwyne, the new editor of the Standard, is well known in Egypt and the Sudan, as he was a special correspondent up the Nile during a number of campaigns.

Mr. C.A. Osborne, of Suakin, who went to Europe last month to consult Professor Pagenstecker, the world-renowned oculist of Wiesbanden, received such benefit from his treatment that he has now left Germany for London and hopes to be able to sail on his return to Suakin about the 20th December.

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: ARRIVAL AT PORT SAID.
NEARLY A COLLISION.
SHIPPING STOPPED.
PRESENCE OF JAPS,
London, November 23.

Reuter's correspondent at Canea confirms the report of the disgraceful conduct of some of the men belonging to the Baltic Fleet. Constant scenes of drunkenness took place in which several officers participated. One Russian was killed by his comrades, whilst others were severly wounded. The officers were disregarded, and there was no discipline. Many of the seamen were left behind, being either lost or having deserted. (Reuter.)
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT)
Port Said, Wednesday.
The Fleet will be off the port at 5 a.m. tomorrow, 24th inst. The Canal Company have allotted berths to them as follows:-
Opposite Rive Asie Island in order running North to South:-
No. 1. Jupiter.
2. Kitai.
3. Setlina.
4. Anathe.
Nos. 5 to 10 Torpedo Destroyers.
No. 11. Lissoi Veliky,
12. Navarin.
13. Almaz.
14. Varoney.
15. Veadimia.
They will be allowed to take fresh water and provisions on board, but no coal.
I have it on good authority that a portion of the Mediterranean Squadron will be within call of the guard-ship here, but cannot say if the Fleet will be followed through the Canal.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Port Said, Wednesday, 9.20 p.m.
The Russian Consul-General and the head officials of the Suez Canal Company have arrived here to-noght. They will meet the Baltic Fleet to-morrow.
The Greek Squadron left a 3 p.m. to-day- It will probably pass the Russians during the night.
The Canal will be cleared of all traffic during the passage of the fleet.
Agents of the Japanese Government are here watching events. Rumors of the presence of Japanese warships off Aden are to hand.
(HAVAS TELEGRAM)
Port Said, November 24.

The Russian Squadron, coming from Suda Bay, is in sight. The ships are entering one after the other. It is believed they will remain a few hours in the port. Every precaution has be taken for their passage through the Canal. The Greek Squadron left yesterday for Syra.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Port Said, Thursday, 11.46 a.m.
At 2 o'clock this morning the Russian Consul-Gerneral, M. Maximoff, and some pilots left the port to meet the fleet on its way here.
At 4 o'clock four of the Russian destroyers arrived and anchored in the outer harbour. Four warships and eight store ships arrived later. The store ships anchored while the warships kept on the move.
At daylight the rest of the flet entered the harbour, and there was nearly a collision.
The ships in the harbour were not allowed to leave while the fleet was entering.
The colliers carry Cardiff coal loaded in Sebastopol. There are naval crews on all the store ships. The officers are reported to be smart, while the crews are very inefficient.

div.head: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGPYTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Sir,-Referring to the Port Said Notes in your issue of yesterday's date, might I suggest that as a measure of precaution the authorities be requested to suspend the firing of the Ramadam gun at Port Said, Ismalia and Suez during the passage of the Baltic Fleet through the Suez Canal. In their present chronic state of nervousness, there is no knowing what the famous Fleet may be capable of doing, if they are startled by the firing of the gun.
I am, etc.,
SHICK YOUSIF.

div.head: Cairo, November 23.
div.p: Says the Pall Mall Gazette:-The Suez Canal is to be padded with cotton wool for the passage of the "Second Pacific Squadron." That is to say, not only will there be special protection of the banks and a suspension of all northward traffic to give the warships an uninterrupted passage, but the captains of all ships are to receive strict orders to refrain from throwing anything into the Canal until the ships are through, and to prevent any kind of demonstration. These precautions are most commendable. The nerves of the North Sea heroes must be thought of. It is terrible to thimk of what might happen if any British mercantile seamen were thoughtless enough to tap out his pipe overboard within sight of a fleet that might misinterpret his action, to say nothing of throwing over ashes or banana-skins. The rule against demonstrations is likewise to the good. A misconcieved wink or simle, seen through a Russian telescope, might produce the direst complications. We have to remember that when such a fleet as this becomes neurotic it is others who suffer.

div.head: SUDDEN DEATH ON BOURSE.
div.p: SENSATION IN CITY.

Mr. Augustine Salvago, a broker belonging to the firm of Cumbo, Maximoff & Co., on the Alexandria Bourse, died under tragic circumstances this morning. At about half-past ten o'clock, he was sitting in the cafe of the Bourse taking a cup of coffee, when he was siezed with a heart failure and died on the spot.

A few minutes before he had received a telegram concerning his business and sat down awaiting a confirmatory wire. While seated he was joined by a friend, who addressed him with a salutation several times but received no reply, as Mr.Salvago had already lost the power of articulation. Seeing that Mr.Salvago was seriously ill, he called for a waiter, who fetched Dr. Lian, the latter happening to be on the Bourse. Dr. Lian was afterwards joined by another medical man, and both did everything called for by the circumstances, but unavailingly. Mr. Salvago was removed to a bench in the Bourse, where he died a few minutes afterwards, without having again spoken. His body was subsequently removed to his residence.
Deceased, who was about 50 years of age, leaves a widow and three children, two of whom are girls.
The occurrence caused a great sensation in the city, and crowds gathered in the immediate neigbourhood of the Bourse. Business was suspended for fifteen minutes as a sign of respect.

After Mr. Salvago had breathed his last a disgraceful scence occurred in the cafe, where the corpse lay. Crowds of eager sightseers jostled one another in their desire to view the body. The coffee tables and chairs were used as points of vantage, and the crowding was terrible. No serious attempt was made to deal with the crowd.

div.head: DEATH OF BEWLEY BEY.
div.p: The death of Bewley Bey in England yesterday, announced in a private telegram received by us this morning, has been expected for some time as he was in failing health for many months and was suffering from an incurable malady, viz., spinal paralysis. Lately he had completely lost his reason, which necessitated his being put under restraint and confined in a private home.

Bewley Bey, who was related to the late Captain Beyts of Suez, came out originally to Europe about 30 years ago and was employed for a short time in the firm of Beytz & Co. of that town. He subsequently joined the ill-fated expedition that was sent to Suakin shortly after under Baker Pasha, and on the almost completeannihilation of that force that followed, he was appointed to the police service. He was afterwards named director of the Public Security Department at the Ministry of the Interior, succeeding Colonel Kelly Bey, on the latter's retirement about three years ago, to the important post of director of the Police Stores Department at Boulac on a salary of L.E. 900 per annum.
Bewley Bey, who left Cairo last summer on sick leave, leaves a widow and several children, for whom the deepest sympathy is felt by the whole British community of the Capital.
Deceased was in posession of the Egyptian Medal and Bronze Star, as well as the 4th Class Medijidieh and 4th Class Osmanieh.

div.head: CANAL NAVIGATION.
div.p: All the canals in Menoufieh and Gharbieh provinces will be lowered or closed for works in connection with the annual clearances on December 20, and navigation will be difficult, if not impossible, from that date until the 20th of January.
The lock at Santa will be completely closed to navigation and the Bagouria Canal will be quite impassable; therefore, through navigation from Alexandria to Cairo will only be possible by the river.

In consequence of winter clearances the canals in 1st Circle of Irrigation will be closed from December 20 for about 30 days with the exception of the Ismalia Canal, which will be open for the navigation of small boats only.
Navigation in Gharbieh province will be stopped in all canals from 15th December, for about 30 days.
Navigation in Dakalieh province will be stopped in all canals from 10th December, for about 30 days.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY.
div.p: The committee of the Khedivial Agricultural Society has approved the scheme for the extension of the work of this society which has been under consideration for some time past.
The general meeting of the society, which will be held shortly, will discuss the decisions arrived at by the committee and decide on the measures to be taken.
The Government is doing everything to further the work of the society, and in future, we understand, a few officials of the Government will have a seat on the committee.

div.head: ALAHAMBRA THEATRE.
div.p: Last night, on the occasion of the final appearance of the tenor G. Apostolu, Rigoletto was given. The theatre vas crowded, and the artistes were frantically applauded. Foremost amongst them we may mention Mme Aida Gonzaga, who, in the role of Gilda, displayed the full force of her talent as a singer and comedienne. The barytone Arrighetti was perfect in the two first acts, but appeared tired towards the end. The tenor Apostolu was splendid from beginning to end. He had to repeat "Donna e mobile" in the 4th act. The orchestra played admirable throughout the piece.
